text:
This looks amazing - congrats!
I find the demo totally overwhelming though. It would take me some time just to read and understand a static screenshot but then it all starts moving and there are subtitles going on in parallel so there is about 5x more happening I can possibly take in. I watched most of it but didn't learn much other than being dazzled.
It's quite shock how little people can absorb from a demo. Got to go slow and be really specific with lots of context about the why not just the how. I'm usually the one causing the confusion so I know what this type of feedback feels like :smile:

text: Yes, you are right about the speed and amount of stuff, but there seems to be an impossible to achieve balance where people just don't watch videos longer than 3 or 4 minutes (I think the usual limit is 2) to see if they are interested in something "because they need it" (as opposed to "because the are inherently interested"). This video was recorded for a conference this week to be looping in the background with other videos, the idea is to "pick up interest to dig further or to start a conversation", for more detailed and "pick your own pace" style of content I plan to expand and improve <https://instadeq.com/tour/> and <https://instadeq.com/tour/workspaces/>

text: I think multimedia explainer pages would be better to explain it in detail and allow people to go at their own pace, the following weeks I will expand the feature tour pages <https://instadeq.com/tour/workspaces/> but video is easier to share on social media, nobody follows a link to a page these days, it must be embeded and short :stuck_out_tongue:

text: One cheat for video editing which is pretty easy is to create a powerpoint/keynote for text, arrows, overlays and transitions and then just record a video of it.

elements.text: One cheat for video editing which is pretty easy is to create a powerpoint/keynote for text, arrows, overlays and transitions and then just record a video of it.

text:
> impossible to achieve balance
I think it's like writing. It's hopefully not impossible just really hard and requires incredible iteration and editing to really distill down to the most minimal and easy to understand action that transmits understanding. i.e. showing one thing really well instead of 10 things poorly.

elements.text: impossible to achieve balance

I think it's like writing. It's hopefully not impossible just really hard and requires incredible iteration and editing to really distill down to the most minimal and easy to understand action that transmits understanding. i.e. showing one thing really well instead of 10 things poorly.

text: I think longer tutorial videos work but need a warm and engaging narration and solving a problem that resonates.

elements.text: I think longer tutorial videos work but need a warm and engaging narration and solving a problem that resonates.

text: When it's just demoing different types of interaction without much narrative to tie them together then I would probably prefer a web page with explanation interspersed with very short videos. Maybe a bit more like <https://reactjs.org/> in spirit.

elements.text: When it's just demoing different types of interaction without much narrative to tie them together then I would probably prefer a web page with explanation interspersed with very short videos. Maybe a bit more like
in spirit.

text: regarding powerpoint/keynote, you embed the video segments in the slides with autoplay?

elements.text: regarding powerpoint/keynote, you embed the video segments in the slides with autoplay?

text: regarding a web page, yes, I want to explore the idea of "what if we gave as much attention to onboarding documentation as to the application itself", or another/complementary take "what if the onboarding documentation was an application itself"

elements.text: regarding a web page, yes, I want to explore the idea of "what if we gave as much attention to onboarding documentation as to the application itself", or another/complementary take "what if the onboarding documentation was an application itself"

text:
> You embed the video segments in the slides with autoplay?

I think when I last did it this way, I had overlays on static screen shots and played clips inbetween. It was a back against the wall rush job!

Should be possible over video though e.g.

<https://support.office.com/en-us/article/trigger-an-animation-effect-651726d6-9454-4bfd-b8e5-11d84767a6da>

text:
The way I'm currently doing it is to be able to play back demo scripts within the app. I would find it just about as easy to add floating callouts in the app itself as I would in a video editor but doing it in-app has the advantage of being useful as an interactive tutorials.

Has pros and cons. It's great for regenerating videos for a fast changing product. But... it's hard to edit the demo scripts naturally. I end up with yet-another-programming-language this time for scripting demos! You have to do odd things like randomise typing delays and fake a mouse cursor to be convincing. It's quite a time-suck so it makes it tricky to recommend.

elements.text:

I end up with yet-another-programming-language this time for scripting demos! You have to do odd things like randomise typing delays and fake a mouse cursor to be convincing. It's quite a time-suck so it makes it tricky to recommend.

text: Well you don't need 60fps for most UIs, complex or not! The virtual DOM allows a clean (often pure-ish, sort of functional) model to be implemented efficiently enough for most purposes

elements.text: Well you don't need 60fps for most UIs, complex or not! The virtual DOM allows a clean (often pure-ish, sort of functional) model to be implemented efficiently enough for most purposes

text: It's more efficient than managing the DOM API yourself for most purposes, because no matter how complex your UI and event chains, you only make the updates that are needed

elements.text: It's more efficient than managing the DOM API yourself for most purposes, because no matter how complex your UI and event chains, you only make the updates that are needed

text: I use imgui in free-fps style, with a good old fps counter - it's coming down gradually towards 60fps as I make the UI more complex

elements.text: I use imgui in free-fps style, with a good old fps counter - it's coming down gradually towards 60fps as I make the UI more complex

text: Rendering nested objects is quite demanding: I tried it on an equivalent Android Java 2D UI and it simply ground to a halt!

elements.text: Rendering nested objects is quite demanding: I tried it on an equivalent Android Java 2D UI and it simply ground to a halt!
